You raise an essential point, and ethical considerations surrounding human colonization on other planets are a subject of ongoing debate. As far as we know, Mars and other planets and moons in our solar system are uninhabited by any other known organisms, but the possibility of discovering life in these locations still remains a possibility. 

If microbial or other life forms are discovered on these planets, it would raise significant ethical questions about the colonization and exploration of the planet. The ethical considerations would revolve around the potential impact of human settlement on these ecosystems, as well as our responsibilities to preserve them for scientific study and future generations.

Many experts argue that before we begin considering colonization of other planets, we need to establish ethical guidelines for exploration and potential settlement. These guidelines would need to address issues such as environmental protection, cultural preservation, and human rights. 

At the same time, the development of technologies and infrastructure for space exploration and colonization has the potential to benefit and advance science and humankind as a whole. It is essential to balance these benefits with the need to minimize the impact on the planetary ecosystems we may encounter. 

Ultimately, it is up to governments and international organizations to establish ethical guidelines and policies for human exploration and colonization on other planets, taking into account the potential impact on the local ecosystems and any life forms that may exist there.
